comment: To maneuver the knight to e3 putting pressure on Black's d5 and f5. This procedure was originated by Steinitz in one of the games of his match with Blackburne in 1876. Later it became standard in many variations of the Lopez. Also very good was first 0-0 and then Re1 followed by Nf1. But Steinitz was fond of delaying castling when such a strategy was playable In this way he kept open the option of castling on the queenside.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by highlighting the strategic reasons behind the move, referencing historical strategies, and suggesting alternative moves that could have been better.
moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. d3 d6 5. c3 g6 6. Nbd2 Bg7 7. Nf1
context: This is a game between Steinitz (as White) and Tchigorin (as Black). Last move played: White plays Knight to f1
reformulated: The move to Nf3 was strategically flawed. This maneuver, which targets Black's pawn on d5 and controls the diagonal over f5, is historically linked to Steinitz's game against Blackburne in the 1876 match. Although this tactic is prevalent in Lopez variations, it's essential to note that Steinitz preferred delaying castling when such tactics could be employed. This approach allows White to keep the possibility of castling on the queenside.

comment: There is a good point to this seeming waste of time. White plans to respond with Qe2 if Black should play d5 guarding his king pawn and preventing the exchange of queens. If Black should then play Bd7 White wants to have a retreat for his king bishop at c2 so that Black cannot force its exchange with Nd4.
reasoning: The comment actually describes a potential follow-up plan for White, not a mistake made by the player.

comment: This would be a good move if Black planned to follow it up with Nb6 and d5 advancing in the center. However Black played it with the idea of continuing in this way; Nc5 Ne6 (The knight will be loose on c5 after Black plays d5.) Ne7 and finally d5. An awfully slow plan! Black had two good alternatives; 8...a6 followed by b5 and d5 (or Na5 followed by c5 putting pressure on Whites d4 if White plays Bb3 instead of of Bc2 and 8...d5 at once. Indeed there is a certain logic to the latter move; White has lost a tempo with 8. Ba4 so Black can afford to lose one by moving his queen pawn twice.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by Black, as it highlights the slow and passive nature of the move, while also pointing out better alternatives available to the player.

reformulated: "White's last move was questionable as it seemed to indicate a slow plan for Black, involving Nc5, Ne6, Ne7, and finally d5. Black had more dynamic options available, such as 8...a6 followed by b5 and d5 or Na5 with c5 to exert pressure on White's d4. White lost a tempo with 8. Ba4, giving Black the opportunity to strategically weaken White's position by advancing the queen pawn twice."
